mainContent.text:
3.5 Synthesizing Information

        Completion requirements
        



Synthesis is Creating
The highest level of thinking, according to Bloom's Taxonomy in 1956, used to be "Evaluating," or deciding what information or decision is best.  Nearly a century later, the world has changed, largely due to technology, the Digital Revolution, thus
    issuing in the Information Age.  A century later, the highest level of thinking, according to Bloom's (Revised) Taxonomy in 2001, is now "Synthesis," or "Creating" new information from all sources available.  

"Synthesizing" is the act of "filtering" all the available sources down to the most important ones in order to create a new kind of source.  In effect, academic research is the act of synthesizing primary, secondary, and tertiary sources in order to create a new "fourth" level source.  So, the act of filtering good sources using a database is an essential skill we want you to learn here at Silicon Valley High School.

Academic research has much higher standards than simple "Google" searching.  In academic writing and research, teachers want sources that have been "vetted," or screened, hand-picked as quality sources by librarians and researchers.  A source
    written by an expert, a doctor, or a specialist is much more valuable than that written by an unknown, a student, or a biased blogger.  So, as a "synthesizer" yourself, you will be asked to filter information using managed databases like  Google Scholar!

Watch the following videos to learn more:





Reading:
Step-by-Step Guide to Writing a Synthesis Paper
